questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'I have to manage this affair carefully. Grace must never suspect that I did this on purpose...'

(i) Who said this and what is the name of the story?
(ii) What was the affair that needed to be managed carefully?
(iii) What reason did the speaker give for not accepting the invitation? What was the real reason?
(iv) What was the name of the place the invitation was to?
(v) Where did the speaker go for her holidays and how did she feel about it?
questions.answer:
(i) Bertha said this. The name of the story is 'The Picture Frame' by Lilian Gask.

(ii) The affair that needed to be managed carefully was declining the invitation to Dovedell Hall while making it appear that she genuinely could not go, rather than revealing she didn't want Grace to go there.

(iii) Bertha gave the excuse that she could not leave her delicate aunt alone during the holidays. The real reason was that she was jealous of Grace and didn't want her to enjoy the luxuries at Dovedell Hall.

(iv) The invitation was to Dovedell Hall, Doris Dovedell's country home.

(v) Bertha went to stay with her aunt for the holidays. She felt miserable and bored as there was nothing exciting to do there.
key_points: Didn't want Grace at Dovedell Hall

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'It's really fortunate the term is almost out, for I'm nearly bankrupt. I have just enough left to furnish a tuck out for commencement night and no more.'

(i) Who said these words and to whom?
(ii) Why was the speaker bankrupt? What was she celebrating?
(iii) Where were they having this conversation?
(iv) What did the speaker say about her aunt?
(v) What did her friend feel after hearing all this?
questions.answer:
(i) Bertha said these words to Grace.

(ii) Bertha was bankrupt because she had spent all her pocket money on buying clothes, treats, and other things during the school term. She was celebrating the end of the school term (commencement).

(iii) They were having this conversation at school, likely in their dormitory or common room.

(iv) Bertha said that her aunt was delicate and that she would have to spend the holidays with her, implying it would be a boring time.

(v) Grace felt sorry for Bertha after hearing about her boring holiday plans. She wished she could help her friend have a better time.

questions.question: Why did Bertha not want Grace to work at Clarkman's bookstore for the summer? What does this tell us about the kind of person she was?
questions.answer: Bertha didn't want Grace to work at Clarkman's bookstore because she was jealous and selfish. She couldn't bear the thought of Grace earning her own money and becoming independent. This tells us that Bertha was a jealous, possessive, and insecure person who wanted to keep Grace dependent on her so she could feel superior. She pretended to be a good friend but was actually manipulative and envious of Grace.
key_points: Didn't want Grace to be independent

questions.question: What all did her aunt tell Bertha while inviting her for the holidays?
questions.answer: Aunt Margaret wrote to Bertha inviting her to spend the holidays at her place. She mentioned that though her home was simple, Bertha would have fresh country air, good food, and peaceful surroundings. The aunt also said that Bertha could bring a friend along if she wished. She promised to make the stay comfortable and enjoyable despite the modest arrangements.

questions.question: What did Aunt Margaret write to Bertha to make her want to go to her place for the holidays?
questions.answer: Aunt Margaret wrote a warm and inviting letter to Bertha, describing the pleasures of spending holidays at her country home. She mentioned the fresh air, beautiful countryside, and peaceful environment that would provide a welcome change from school life. The aunt assured Bertha that though her home was modest, she would be well taken care of with good home-cooked food and comfortable accommodation. She also encouraged Bertha to bring along a school friend to keep her company, showing her generous and hospitable nature. The aunt's letter painted a picture of simple but genuine hospitality, which made Bertha consider the invitation, though she was also looking for more exciting options.

questions.question: Why was Grace shy with Bertha at first? Do you think Bertha was a good friend? Explain your answer.
questions.answer: Grace was shy with Bertha at first because of their different social and financial backgrounds. Grace was poor and had lost her mother, wearing mourning clothes, while Bertha came from a more comfortable background. Grace felt inferior and uncertain about how to interact with someone who seemed to have so much more. She was also naturally reserved and didn't want to impose herself on others. However, Bertha was NOT a good friend. Though she appeared friendly on the surface, she was actually jealous, manipulative, and selfish. She deliberately prevented Grace from going to Dovedell Hall because she couldn't bear Grace enjoying luxuries. She also didn't want Grace to work and become independent. A true friend would have been happy for Grace's opportunities rather than secretly sabotaging them.
key_points: Grace was poor and in mourning
Bertha was NOT a good friend

questions.question: Grace wanted to work at Clarkman's bookstore because ___.
options: A. She wanted to pass time
B. She wanted to read books
C. She wanted to stay away from Bertha
D. She needed money to pay her fees
questions.correct_answer: D. She needed money to pay her fees
questions.explanation: Grace was poor and needed to earn money to pay for her school fees, which is why she wanted to work at Clarkman's bookstore during the summer.

questions.question: Grace was dressed in mourning because ___.
options: B. Her aunt had just died
C. She liked dressing like that
D. She had nothing else to wear
questions.explanation: Grace was dressed in mourning (black clothes) because her mother had passed away, leaving her an orphan.

questions.question: Bertha gave Grace the news of the invitation right after her ___ examination.
questions.explanation: Bertha chose to tell Grace about the invitation to Dovedell Hall right after Grace's History examination.
